ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I learned a much more substantial understanding of the Spanish language. I feel like I left the class with a foundation of knowledge that I can build on as I continue to learn. 

It was really fun to feel myself gaining fluency in speaking and writing as the course went on. That gave me confidence that I can continue developing such fluency. 

I also learned a lot content-wise from the theater, film, literature, environmental, and other aspects of the Spanish-speaking world we engaged.
I became more proficient in my Spanish writing, speaking, and reading. I also gained a deeper understanding of both Spanish & Latin American cultures.
Better Spanish knowledge
I developed my writing skills more than anything else in this course.
I learned more Spanish vocabulary and grammatical structures.
A more advanced knowledge of the spanish language.
I learned about different Spanish-speaking cultures and re-learned some important vocab and grammar.
By taking this course, I learned about the culture of Spanish speaking countries as well as how to speak for fluently with known vocabulary and sentence structures.
Reading in writing in Spanish language through tenses and grammar as listed on the syllabus. Cultural/historical insights into Spain and Latin America.
My Spanish speaking, writing, and readings significantly improved by taking this course.
Even though I developed skills in the language of Spanish, I feel that I mostly gained knowledge about different aspects of different hispanic cultures.
My understanding of the culture of Spanish speaking countries was greatly increased.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the professor was amazing (more on that below), the content was interesting, and the course consistently required you to write, read, speak, and think in Spanish

Weaknesses: the only thing to come to mind is that sometimes the assignments felt unnecessarily complex, even meta (e.g. giving a presentation primarily about what it was like for us to create a magazine cover for the presentation). With that, it sometimes felt like the arbitrary but quite specific requirements of the assignment actually inhibited me from diving into language learning. In those moments, it felt like content learning or even production was being prized more highly than language learning (which is why I was in the course)

strengths: the course content was often quite interesting, particularly as the semester went on. We watched films and shorts that addressed topics like neocolonialism and bioethics that I haven't encountered too much in my other courses. There's a pretty consistent workload, so I was forced to practice on a near-daily basis.

weaknesses: the workload, while being consistent, is often quite high. There are sometimes multiple assignments due simultaneously, between all of the different moving parts of the course. While I think I got a lot out of the varied types of assignments (written paragraphs, group presentations, essays), it certainly could feel overwhelming at times. I'd recommend adding more oral assignments; while we do talk in class, I think my speaking skills would've improved some by replacing a few of the writing assignments with oral ones.
Too many times a week it was exhausting. Give one day off a week
I think that a weakness could be how much work was needed to be done prior to class. Often I would not be able to finish all of the work and was left with an ineffective class.
No weaknesses. I enjoyed the projects.

The cultural media was excellent. Class format (small groups, daily meetings) contributed significantly to content delivery. Course design should incorporate more mandatory oral participation, particularly listening.
The assignments for this course were incredibly diverse, so you didn't get tired of the coursework.

I don't believe there are any weaknesses of this course. Everyone is engaging everyday, which creates a good learning environment. I believe the strengths are in the assignments in which we are assigned. We utilize what we learn grammatically in the various culture assignments, so we are learning double.
The course did not advance our understanding of new Spanish grammar as far as it focused on our understanding of Spanish cultures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I'd recommend this course to anyone who wants a really good way to work on learning Spanish.

I'm guessing that most people taking this course are doing so to fulfill their language requirement. However, I'd highly recommend taking the course with Mara. She's a wonderful instructor; class is interactive and engaging.
I would highly recommend this course to another student as it is well-organized. I loved having each Wednesday to work at my own pace. I also enjoyed the more creative projects.
Yes it was a solid class to take
Yes. L3 is a great spanish to take.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student that is fulfilling the language requirement or trying to learn Spanish at Yale.
Yes. I love Spanish and I think it is very useful.
Yes! Great class to solidify your Spanish skills.
Yes, but it depends if they are interested in learning Spanish or not because you have to be into it in order to get something out of it.
Yes, this course is for any student who wants to understand the cultural nuances of Spanish speaking countries.
